title: My book has chapter lengths varying from 2,000 to 7,000 words. Is this okay? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sorry but who cares! write the book, when you have finished it, read it. you will know then if the chapters are to short or too long; then you edit it. it is all about experience. I have never ever once counted how many words i have done in a single chapter. it has never even occurred to me to do a word count on a single chapter. you aren't writing an essay where the word count matters. Worrying about this kind of stuff is a waste of time and energy. when i first started writing novels, my first draft of my first novel was a thousand pages long. some chapters had twenty to fifty pages in them. i cut four hundred pages in that first edit, whole chapters. i cut the chapters down to a manageable size. i began to stream line the whole novel. your first challenge is to write and finish the first draft. until then stop wasting your time and energy worrying about stuff like this.

I don’t know what your book is about or what makes your chapters so variable, but if was my book I would try to reduce the larger chapters to something like 5,000 words. This is only because shorter chapters have a allusion for readers of faster paced writing. Also your longest chapters become a temptation for readers to put the book down. They may never pick it up again, and so not recommend your work to others. The modern idea is to have shorter chapters than has usually been the case; readers feel like they are making good progress in their reading.

A chapter needs to be as long as it needs to be to accomplish the beginning and ending of a scene. Just make sure every word counts. For now, worry about getting it written. Cut the fluff and kill your darlings during the edits. This is for a story, of course, fiction or not. If academic, I got nothing.

Is your writing a little wordy, or is it rather deep? The 7000 might be a little long. Just so you know, a lot of very popular writers use very short chapters. Of course, I’m talking here of mostly genre, with lots of action.

Personally, it is not about rules carved in stone on number of words per paragraph or per chapter. Since you are the author, you will know if an idea or plot is contained within that chapter. If the chapter contains multiple plots or subplots, then why not break it up into chapters. Chapters are free. Help the reader (consumer) digest the story the best you can.

Depends on the type of book - and that word denotes non-fiction, whose pages can be longer. Novel chapters can also be longer but the fashion of best-sellers these days, like James Patterson novels, is about in the middle per chapter of the lengths you listed.

Quantity v Quality = your reader is interested in the story. If you need 7000 words to capture the action and suspense, use 7000 words. What needs to be avoided is writing lots of details that are not important. It slows the plot down and bores the reader to death. Every success.
That is fine.. it’s more about feel in my opinion. Depending on overall length you could consider splitting it into parts within the same book. Good luck!
Thanks for the A2A. That’s pretty normal. Chapters are only as long, or as short as they have to be to tell that part of the story.

I find that for myself, a chapter of 2600–4000 words works best (fantasy genre). As others have said, the chapter needs to be long enough to get to the end. But it’s important to keep the writing lean and tight, which will lend itself to shorter chapters.
